content:
{{knowledge objective
|Identifiant=OIC-265-09-B
|Item_parent=Urinary lithiasis
|Item_parent_short=Urinary lithiasis
|Rank=B
|Title=Knowing other clinical aspects of urinary calculi
|Description=Hematuria, renal failure, infection, incidental
|Rubric=Positive diagnosis
|Contributors=Romain Boissier
|Order=9}}

The symptoms associated with a urinary calculus, other than renal colic, are :

*none: asymptomatic stone discovered by chance
*[[Haematuria|haematuria 260]], rather of effort. macroscopic or microscopic
*[[Urinary infections of children and adults|urinary infections 161]] (pyelonephritis)
*[[Chronic renal insufficiency in adults and children|renal insufficiency 264]] (chronic obstruction and coralliform stones)

question.title: What are the symptoms associated with a urinary calculus, other than renal colic?

option_a.title: Painful urination
option_a.description: A common symptom of urinary calculi

option_b.title: Haematuria
option_b.description: A symptom that can be microscopic or macroscopic

option_d.title: Loss of appetite
option_d.description: A symptom that can be associated with chronic renal insufficiency

correct_option.title: None of the above
correct_option.description: The correct answer is not listed
